intro: Calostephane setosa, commonly known as the hairy calostephane, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that are clustered in umbels, a typical feature of the family. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal potential, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
